questions.text: A 52-year-old male undergoes abdominal surgery under general anaesthesia with vecuronium. In the recovery room, he shows delayed return of spontaneous breathing. He had received an IV antibiotic intraoperatively. Which of the following antibiotics most likely caused this delayed recovery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Gentamicin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, is known to potentiate the effect of non-depolarising muscle relaxants (NDMRs) such as vecuronium or rocuronium. This results in delayed recovery from neuromuscular blockade after general anaesthesia.

  • Aminoglycosides, along with polymyxins, lincomycin, and clindamycin, interfere at the neuromuscular junction by:
    • Inhibiting the prejunctional release of acetylcholine.
    • Reducing the sensitivity of postsynaptic nicotinic acetylcholine receptors to acetylcholine.
  • This dual action significantly enhances and prolongs neuromuscular blockade.

Explanation of other options:

Penicillin (Option A): Penicillins do not have any neuromuscular blocking properties.

Erythromycin (Option B): Erythromycin (a macrolide) is not commonly associated with significant neuromuscular blockade.

Cefazolin (Option D): Cephalosporins, like penicillins, do not interfere with neuromuscular transmission.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is scheduled for elective herniotomy under general anaesthesia. The anaesthesiologist plans to administer a neuromuscular blocking agent to facilitate routine endotracheal intubation. Considering the age of the child and the safety profile of muscle relaxants, which of the following is the most appropriate drug to use?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rocuronium is the preferred muscle relaxant for routine intubation in children due to:

  • Rapid Onset & Good Intubating Conditions Rocuronium 1.2 mg/kg provides excellent intubating conditions in 65% and good in 25% at 45 seconds, comparable to succinylcholine but without its adverse effects.
  • Hemodynamic Stability: In that trial, rocuronium maintained stable heart rate and blood pressure, whereas succinylcholine caused a significant post-intubation tachycardia.
  • Intramuscular Use: Rocuronium is available in IM form, making it suitable when IV access is challenging, an important advantage in pediatric anaesthesia
  • Avoids Succinylcholine Risks: Succinylcholine risks in children include bradycardia, hyperkalemia, malignant hyperthermia, and fasciculations; toxicity concerns are largely absent with rocuronium.

Explanation of other options:

Suxamethonium (Option A) (Succinylcholine): Although it has the fastest onset, it is reserved for emergencies or full-stomach cases due to serious side effects in children

Pancuronium (Option C): Long duration and causes tachycardia and hypertension, undesirable in routine pediatric procedures.

Vecuronium (Option D): Moderate onset, but its duration can be prolonged in infants because of immature hepatic metabolism.

Reference:

  1. ncbi.nlm.nih.gov+6pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov+6aimeairway.ca+6
  2. nlm.nih.gov+4ncbi.nlm.nih.gov+4openanesthesia.org+4

choices.text: Increase the dose of succinyl choline

questions.text: A 28-year-old male undergoing elective hernia repair under general anaesthesia is given succinylcholine for intubation. In recovery, he fails to resume spontaneous breathing 30 minutes after the expected drug action. The anesthesiologist suspects succinylcholine-induced apnea due to atypical pseudocholinesterase. What is the most appropriate immediate management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most appropriate and immediate management in succinylcholine-induced prolonged apnea due to atypical pseudocholinesterase is to maintain airway and ventilation support until spontaneous breathing returns.

  • Succinyl choline is normally broken down rapidly by plasma pseudocholinesterase.
  • In patients with atypical (or deficient) pseudocholinesterase, its metabolism is significantly delayed → resulting in prolonged neuromuscular blockade.
  • Mechanical ventilation is required to maintain oxygenation and ventilation during this time, which can last several hours.

This condition is self-limiting with supportive care. No specific antidote is needed.

Explanation of other options:

Increased succinylcholine dosing (Option A): Contraindicated, would only worsen paralysis.

Fresh Frozen Plasma (Option B) (FFP): May be used to augment butyrylcholinesterase levels and accelerate recovery, particularly in severe or prolonged cases. However, it's not routinely recommended because of infection risk and the generally benign prognosis with supportive care.

Administer Neostigmine (Option D): Contraindicated in succinylcholine-induced (Phase I) block. Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. In a Phase I block (typical of succinylcholine), this can paradoxically worsen paralysis due to prolonged depolarization.

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470596/#:~:text=Adverse%20Effects,-Several%20adverse%20effects&text=Depolarizing%20muscle%20relaxants%3A%20Neostigmine%20should,a%20prolonged%20phase%2D1%20block

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding phase I depolarising neuromuscular block?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Phase I depolarising block, caused by succinylcholine, is typically preceded by visible muscle fasciculations (brief, involuntary muscle contractions).
  • These occur because succinylcholine depolarises the motor end plate, causing a transient activation of muscle fibres before paralysis sets in.
  • The fasciculations are a hallmark clinical sign that distinguishes depolarising from non-depolarising neuromuscular blockade.

Explanation of other options:

Reversed by cholinesterase inhibitor (Option A): Incorrect. In the Phase I block, using cholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine increases acetylcholine levels at the neuromuscular junction. This prolongs depolarisation and intensifies the block, rather than reversing it. Hence, cholinesterase inhibitors are contraindicated during Phase I block.

Presence of fade phenomenon (Option B): Incorrect. Fade refers to a progressive decrease in the strength of twitches during repetitive nerve stimulation (e.g., train-of-four or tetanic stimulation). Phase I blocks do not show fade; all twitches are equally reduced. Fade is characteristic of Phase II (or non-depolarising) blocks, not Phase I.

Presence of post-tetanic facilitation (Option D): Incorrect. Post-tetanic facilitation refers to increased twitch strength after a period of tetanic stimulation. This is seen in non-depolarising or Phase II depolarising blocks. In Phase I, the endplate remains persistently depolarised and unresponsive, so no post-tetanic facilitation is observed.

questions.text: Reversal of neuromuscular blockade is accomplished with all except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Glycopyrrolate is not a reversal agent for neuromuscular blockade.
  • It is an anticholinergic used alongside anticholinesterase agents (like neostigmine or pyridostigmine) to counteract their muscarinic side effects, such as bradycardia, increased secretions, and gastrointestinal motility.
  • It does not reverse neuromuscular blockade on its own.
  • Used in combination, e.g., Neostigmine + Glycopyrrolate.

Explanation of other options:

Neostigmine (Option A): Most commonly used agent for reversal. A cholinesterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction. Reverses non-depolarising neuromuscular blockers (e.g., rocuronium, vecuronium).

Sugammadex (Option C): Used for reversal. A modified gamma-cyclodextrin designed to encapsulate and inactivate steroidal neuromuscular blockers, especially rocuronium and vecuronium. Not effective against benzylisoquinolinium agents (e.g., atracurium).

Pyridostigmine (Option D): Another cholinesterase inhibitor, used less commonly than neostigmine. Slower onset and longer duration. Also requires co-administration with an anticholinergic like glycopyrrolate.

choices.text: Precurarization reduces fasciculations and myalgia associated with Sch
Produces both phase I and phase II block

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Succinylcholine (Sch) is not true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Succinylcholine is a depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent, not a non-depolarising one.

Mechanism of Action:

  • Succinylcholine (Sch) resembles acetylcholine (ACh) and binds to nicotinic ACh receptors at the neuromuscular junction (NMJ).
  • Unlike ACh, Sch is not rapidly degraded by acetylcholinesterase at the synapse. Instead, it persists, causing:
    • Continuous depolarisation of the motor endplate (Phase I block)
    • Inactivation of voltage-gated sodium channels prevents further muscle contraction.
  • Leads to flaccid paralysis after initial muscle fasciculations.

Types of Neuromuscular Block:

  1. Phase I block (Depolarising block):
    • Sustained depolarization
    • No fade with Train-of-Four (TOF) or tetanic stimulation
    • No post-tetanic facilitation
    • Not reversed by anticholinesterases (e.g., neostigmine)
  2. Phase II block (Desensitisation block):
    • Occurs with higher or prolonged doses
    • Repolarisation occurs, but the receptor behaves abnormally
    • Mimics a non-depolarising block
    • Shows fade and post-tetanic facilitation
    • May be partially reversed with anticholinesterases

Explanation of Other Options:

Precurarization reduces fasciculations and myalgia associated with Sch (Option A): Giving a small dose (about 10% of ED95) of a non-depolarising agent before succinylcholine (termed precurarization) reduces muscle fasciculations, postoperative myalgia and rise in ICP or IOP. It partially blocks receptors, reducing succinylcholine's intensity of depolarisation.

Produces both phase I and phase II block (Option C): At standard doses, succinylcholine produces a Phase I depolarising block. At high or repeated doses, it can lead to Phase II block, which mimics non-depolarising block (fade on TOF, post-tetanic facilitation).

Rise in intracranial pressure seen (Option D): Due to fasciculations, succinylcholine can cause a transient rise in ICP, IOP, and intragastric pressure. Often attenuated by precurarization or administering a defasciculating dose.

questions.text: Mivacurium is short acting due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Mivacurium is a short-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent. Its brief duration of action is due to rapid enzymatic hydrolysis by butyrylcholinesterase (also called pseudocholinesterase or plasma cholinesterase) present in plasma.

Mivacurium:

  • Belongs to the benzylisoquinolinium class of non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agents.
  • Onset: 2-3 minutes
  • Duration: 10-20 minutes
  • Metabolism: Plasma cholinesterase hydrolyses mivacurium into inactive metabolites, terminating its effect quickly.
  • In patients with pseudocholinesterase deficiency, the blockade can be significantly prolonged, just like with succinylcholine.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Rapid absorption (Option A): Mivacurium is administered intravenously, so absorption is not a limiting factor. This does not affect its duration.

Rapid excretion (Option C): It is not excreted unchanged in urine or bile to a significant degree. Hydrolysis governs its termination.

choices.text: Switch over to atracurium instead of succinyl choline
Cool the child by using a cooling blanket

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with previous uneventful general anaesthesia exposure was given intravenous succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation at a dose of 0.5 mg/kg. During intubation, masseteric spasm was noted. Considering the other vital to be normal, what would your first line of management be?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • This child received a suboptimal dose of succinylcholine. The recommended IV dose for children is 1-2 mg/kg.
  • A dose <1 mg/kg may result in incomplete neuromuscular blockade, leading to masseteric spasm, which is not uncommon in pediatric practice.
  • Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to administer the full dose of succinylcholine (up to 2 mg/kg) and monitor closely.

Signs suggestive of Malignant Hypertension (monitor continuously):

  • Generalised muscle rigidity (especially trunk/extremities)
  • Hypercapnia (rising EtCO2 despite ventilation)
  • Tachycardia
  • Hyperthermia (late sign)
  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Dark-coloured urine (myoglobinuria)
  • Elevated CK, hyperkalemia

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Switch to atracurium (Option A): Changing to a non-triggering agent is not needed in isolated masseteric spasm unless MH signs develop.

IV Dantrolene (Option C): Dantrolene is indicated only if MH is strongly suspected or confirmed. Here, no signs of hypermetabolic crisis are present.

Cooling blanket (Option D): Cooling is part of MH management, not indicated in isolated spasm without hyperthermia.

choices.text: Rapid onset and short duration of action

questions.text: Which of the following is an incorrect statement concerning rapacuronium?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rapacuronium is a non-depolarising muscle relaxant designed for rapid sequence intubation due to its fast onset and short duration of action.

However, it causes dose-related bronchospasm, likely due to:

  • M2 muscarinic receptor antagonism, which increases acetylcholine release at airway smooth muscle → bronchoconstriction
  • Direct stimulation of M3 receptors in airway smooth muscle

It was withdrawn from the market in 2001 due to significant bronchospasm risk, especially in asthmatics and children.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rapid onset and short duration of action (Option A): True. Rapacuronium was introduced as a rapid-onset alternative to succinylcholine, with intubating conditions comparable to succinylcholine but without depolarising side effects.

Non-depolarising muscle relaxant (Option C): True. It is an aminosteroid non-depolarising agent, similar in structure to vecuronium but modified for faster kinetics.

Minimal cardiovascular side effects (Option D): True. Rapacuronium causes minimal changes in heart rate or blood pressure, unlike pancuronium, which may cause tachycardia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with end-stage renal disease (ESRD) is scheduled for elective surgery under general anaesthesia. Which neuromuscular blocking agent would be the most appropriate choice, considering the patient's renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atracurium undergoes Hofmann elimination, a non-enzymatic, organ-independent degradation that depends on physiologic pH and temperature, not renal or hepatic function.
  • Therefore, its clearance is not affected by renal failure, making it the muscle relaxant of choice in patients with renal insufficiency or failure.
  • Cisatracurium, a stereoisomer of atracurium, is also a safe alternative and has fewer histamine-related side effects.

Explanation of other options:

Vecuronium (Option A): Primarily eliminated via bile, but ~25-30% is renally excreted. In renal failure, its duration is prolonged, and recovery may be delayed.

Pipecuronium (Option C): Heavily dependent on renal excretion. Renal failure greatly prolongs its action, making it unsuitable.

Pancuronium (Option D): Primarily excreted unchanged by the kidneys. It is contraindicated or used with extreme caution in renal failure due to the risk of prolonged neuromuscular blockade.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about cisatracurium is true?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cisatracurium, a stereoisomer of atracurium, does not cause histamine release, even at higher doses.
  • This makes it hemodynamically more stable, especially in critically ill or cardiovascularly compromised patients.

Explanation of other options:

No laudanosine production (Option A): Incorrect. Cisatracurium does produce laudanosine (a CNS stimulant), but in much smaller quantities than atracurium, about one-fifth the amount.

Less potent than atracurium (Option C): Incorrect. Cisatracurium is more potent than atracurium, approximately 3-4 times more potent.

Contraindicated in renal failure (Option D): Incorrect. Cisatracurium is not contraindicated in renal failure. It is the agent of choice as it undergoes organ-independent Hofmann elimination.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male with right-sided hemiplegia following a cerebrovascular accident 3 months ago is scheduled for surgery under general anaesthesia. The anesthesiologist is selecting an appropriate neuromuscular blocker for intubation. Which of the following agents should be avoided?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Succinyl choline, a depolarising neuromuscular blocker, is contraindicated in patients with upper motor neuron lesions such as stroke, spinal cord injury, or hemiplegia due to the risk of severe hyperkalemia.

  • Mechanism: After denervation or disuse atrophy (as in hemiplegia), extrajunctional acetylcholine receptors proliferate in affected muscles. Succinylcholine activates these receptors, leading to a massive efflux of potassium from cells into the bloodstream, which can cause ventricular arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.
  • This risk is not related to serum potassium levels before surgery and can occur 2-3 days to months after the neurologic event.
  • Therefore, in hemiplegic or paraplegic patients, even those with previously uneventful surgeries, succinylcholine is avoided.

Conditions causing susceptibility to succinyl choline-induced hyperkalaemia:

  • Burn injury
  • Massive trauma
  • Severe intra-abdominal infection
  • Spinal cord injury
  • Encephalitis
  • Stroke
  • Guillain-Barre syndrome
  • Severe Parkinson’s disease
  • Tetanus
  • Prolonged total body immobilisation
  • Ruptured cerebral aneurysm
  • Polyneuropathy
  • Closed head injury
  • Haemorrhagic shock with metabolic acidosis
  • Myopathies (e.g., Duchenne’s dystrophy)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Mivacurium (Option A): It is a short-acting, non-depolarising muscle relaxant, metabolised rapidly by plasma cholinesterase. It does not cause hyperkalemia, is safe in renal failure and neurologic conditions, and may cause mild histamine release at higher doses.

Atracurium (Option B): It is an intermediate-acting, non-depolarising agent that is eliminated via Hofmann elimination and ester hydrolysis, making it organ-independent. It is safe in renal failure, liver disease, and neurologic conditions. It can cause histamine release in rapid bolus doses.

Cisatracurium (Option C): It is a stereoisomer of atracurium, with no histamine release. It undergoes Hofmann elimination and is hence preferred in critically ill and renal failure patients. It is safe in hemiplegia or neurologic disorders.

questions.text: Sugammadex is used for the reversal of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sugammadex is the first and only selective relaxant binding agent (SRBA) designed specifically to reverse steroidal non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agents, most effectively rocuronium, followed by vecuronium, and to a much lesser extent, pancuronium.

  • It is a modified γ-cyclodextrin that encapsulates the free rocuronium molecules in plasma, effectively reducing their availability at nicotinic receptors.
  • This results in rapid and complete reversal of neuromuscular blockade, even from profound levels.
  • Sugammadex is renally excreted unchanged, so dose adjustment is required in renal failure.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Atracurium (Option B): Not a steroidal relaxant; it is a benzylisoquinolinium compound. Reversal is done using acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine, not sugammadex.

Mivacurium (Option C): Also, a benzylisoquinolinium compound and short-acting. Rapidly broken down by plasma cholinesterase. Sugammadex is ineffective against mivacurium.

Succinyl choline (Option D): A depolarising neuromuscular blocker. Reversal agents are not routinely used; they wear off quickly. Sugammadex does not affect succinylcholine.

questions.text: Activity of butyryl cholinesterase is reduced by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Butyryl cholinesterase (also known as plasma cholinesterase or pseudocholinesterase) is synthesised in the liver and is responsible for the metabolism of succinylcholine and mivacurium.

Its activity can be significantly reduced in several clinical conditions:

  • Pregnancy (Option A ruled out)
  • Malnutrition (Option B ruled out)
  • Liver disease (Option C ruled out)
  • Advanced age
  • Certain drugs:
    • Oral contraceptives
    • Monoamine oxidase inhibitors (MAOIs)
    • Echothiophate
    • Cytotoxic drugs
    • Neostigmine / Anticholinesterases
    • Metoclopramide

Although reduced activity can prolong the effects of succinylcholine, mild to moderate reductions usually cause only slight prolongation of its neuromuscular blockade effect in most patients.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male with end-stage liver disease is undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation in the ICU. For neuromuscular blockade, he is started on a continuous infusion of a non-depolarising muscle relaxant. After 48 hours, the patient develops generalised tonic-clonic seizures. There is no prior history of epilepsy, and electrolytes and neuroimaging are normal. Which of the following muscle relaxants is most likely responsible for his condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Atracurium is metabolised via Hofmann elimination and ester hydrolysis, producing laudanosine, a CNS stimulant.
  • Laudanosine crosses the blood-brain barrier and can lower the seizure threshold, especially in patients with hepatic dysfunction, where its clearance is impaired.
  • This patient’s hepatic failure and prolonged infusion predisposed him to laudanosine accumulation and seizures.
  • Cisatracuriumis a stereoisomer of atracurium, which results in less laudanosine production than atracurium.

Explanation of other options:

Mivacurium (Option A): Metabolised by plasma cholinesterase; does not form laudanosine.

Rocuronium (Option C: Steroidal relaxant; no laudanosine production.

Pancuronium (Option D): Long-acting, steroidal; associated with tachycardia, not seizures.

choices.text: Facilitate earlier recovery from neuromuscular blockade

questions.text: What is the primary reason atropine is co-administered with neostigmine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases acetylcholine at both nicotinic and muscarinic receptors.

  • While the nicotinic effect helps reverse neuromuscular blockade, the muscarinic stimulation (at parasympathetic sites like the heart and GI tract) leads to bradycardia, bronchospasm, salivation, and abdominal cramps.
  • Atropine, an antimuscarinic agent, blocks these undesirable muscarinic side effects, particularly bradycardia.
  • Hence, atropine is co-administered to balance the cholinergic effects of neostigmine.
  • Glycopyrrolate, a quaternary amine, is another anticholinergic that can be used with the anticholinesterases. It has a lower onset than atropine but does not cause central effects as it does not cross the blood-brain barrier, unlike atropine.

Explanation of Other Options:

Facilitate earlier recovery from neuromuscular blockade (Option A): Atropine does not influence the nicotinic site where muscle recovery occurs.

Minimise nicotinic side effects (Option B): Nicotinic effects like muscle contraction or fasciculations are not affected by atropine; glycopyrrolate/atropine target muscarinic receptors.

Enhance neuromuscular blockade (Option D): Opposite of the goal; atropine is given after surgery to reverse, not enhance, blockade.

questions.text: Which is the shortest-acting muscle relaxant?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Suxamethonium (also called succinylcholine) is a depolarising neuromuscular blocker that:

  • Has an ultra-rapid onset of 30-60 seconds
  • Duration of action: 5-10 minutes
  • It is metabolised by butyrylcholinesterase (plasma cholinesterase), which accounts for its short action.
  • It is ideal for rapid sequence intubation and short procedures
  • Avoid in patients with burns, stroke, neuromuscular diseases, rhabdomyolysis, or susceptibility to malignant hyperthermia due to the risk of hyperkalemia and adverse reactions.

questions.text: Dibucaine number reflects?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dibucaine number is a quantitative assay that reflects the functional quality (i.e., efficiency) of the butyrylcholinesterase enzyme (also known as pseudocholinesterase or plasma cholinesterase), which is responsible for metabolising succinylcholine.

  • Dibucaine, a local anaesthetic, inhibits normal (typical) cholinesterase but does not inhibit atypical variants of the enzyme as effectively.
  • Thus, the dibucaine number measures the percentage inhibition of enzyme activity by dibucaine.
  • It tells us how well the enzyme works, not how much of it is present.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Activity of cholinesterase enzyme (Option A): Activity is measured by how quickly it hydrolyses substrates like succinylcholine, but this doesn’t tell you about enzyme inhibition or genetic variants.

Quantity of cholinesterase enzyme (Option B): The amount of enzyme in plasma may be low in liver disease or pregnancy, but the dibucaine number is normal in such cases; it only reflects quality.

Type of cholinesterase enzyme (Option C): The type (e.g., usual vs. atypical variant) is inferred indirectly, but the dibucaine number doesn't directly identify the type, it tells us how well that type functions.

choices.text: It is contraindicated in patients with myasthenia gravis
It accelerates the onset by 30-60 seconds
It provides intubating conditions equal to succinylcholine
The priming dose is typically 10-20% of ED95

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding the priming technique for non-depolarising neuromuscular blockers?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The priming technique involves giving a small, subparalyzing dose of a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker (typically 10% of the intubating dose or ~20% of ED95) 2 to 4 minutes before the full intubating dose.

  • This accelerates onset by 30-60 seconds, allowing intubation roughly 90 seconds after the second dose.
  • However, the intubating conditions do not match those provided by succinylcholine, which remains superior in rapid sequence intubation quality.

Risks of priming include:

  • Difficulty in swallowing or breathing
  • Increased risk of aspiration
  • Subtle but uncomfortable muscle weakness in awake patients

Contraindicated in patients with:

  • Airway abnormalities
  • Neuromuscular disorders (e.g., myasthenia gravis)
  • Magnesium therapy

Explanation of Other Options:

It is contraindicated in patients with myasthenia gravis (Option A): Priming is contraindicated in patients with increased sensitivity to NMBs (e.g., myasthenia gravis) or those receiving magnesium, due to the risk of excessive weakness and aspiration.

It accelerates onset by 30-60 seconds (Option B): The onset of neuromuscular blockade is accelerated by 30-60 seconds.

The priming dose is typically 10-20% of ED95 (Option D): The priming dose is typically 10-20% of ED95 (the dose causing, on average, 95% suppression of neuromuscular response) or 10% of the intubating dose.

questions.text: Which of the following is safe to use in patients with reactive airway disease?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The benzylisoquinolinium class of drugs comprises atracurium, 51W89, doxacurium, rocuronium, tubocurarine and vecuronium and mivacurium
  • The administration of benzylisoquinolinium neuromuscular blocking drugs (except for cisatracurium) is associated with →histamine release, which may result in →increased airway resistance and bronchospasm in patients with hyperactive airway disease.

questions.text: A muscle relaxant that does not have an active metabolite is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Atracurium is primarily metabolised by:

  • Hofmann elimination (a nonenzymatic process dependent on pH and temperature) and
  • Ester hydrolysis, independent of renal and hepatic function.

Although it produces laudanosine as a metabolite, this is a CNS stimulant and not a neuromuscular blocker.

Thus, atracurium does not yield active metabolites that prolong neuromuscular block.

Explanation of other options:

Pancuronium (Option A): Metabolised partly by the liver, producing 3-OH pancuronium, a weakly active metabolite that may accumulate and cause prolonged block, especially in renal impairment.

Vecuronium (Option B): Hepatically metabolised into 3-OH vecuronium, which retains up to 80% potency. It may contribute to prolonged neuromuscular blockade during infusions or in hepatic/renal dysfunction.

questions.text: Which of the following does not potentiate the action of neuromuscular blocking drugs?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Hyperthermia does not potentiate the effect of neuromuscular blocking drugs. In contrast, hypothermia does potentiate their action by slowing drug metabolism and clearance.
  • Hyperthermia may increase the degradation of some muscle relaxants and reduce their duration of action.

Explanation of Other Options:

Magnesium sulphate (Option A): Potentiates neuromuscular blockade by inhibiting calcium entry into the presynaptic nerve terminal, reducing acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction.

Aminoglycoside antibiotics (Option C) (e.g., gentamicin): Potentiate neuromuscular block by inhibiting prejunctional acetylcholine release and reducing postjunctional receptor sensitivity.

Inhalational anaesthetics (Option D) (e.g., isoflurane, sevoflurane): Potentiate the effects of non-depolarising muscle relaxants by decreasing muscle fibre sensitivity to depolarisation, decreasing the release of acetylcholine and reducing the amount of muscle relaxant needed and prolonging the duration of action

questions.text: Non-depolarising muscle relaxants are?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agents bind to the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor at the neuromuscular junction but do not activate it. Instead, they block ACh from binding and prevent depolarisation. Because they compete with ACh for the receptor binding site, they are classified as competitive antagonists.
  • When sufficient numbers of these receptors are blocked, a neuromuscular blockade ensues, preventing muscle contraction.

Explanation of Other Options:

Non-competitive antagonist (Option A): These agents bind to a different site than the endogenous ligand and inhibit the receptor regardless of ACh levels. Non-depolarising NMBAs do not act this way, they compete at the ACh binding site.

Competitive agonists (Option B): Agonists mimic the action of the natural ligand (ACh), which is not the case here. Non-depolarising agents do not trigger depolarisation or end-plate potentials.

questions.text: Which of the following is a known risk factor for succinylcholine-induced postoperative myalgia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The incidence of muscle pain following succinylcholine administration varies widely, from 0.2% to 89% and is more frequently observed:

  • After minor surgeries
  • In women
  • In ambulatory (mobile) patients, as opposed to bedridden individuals

Proposed Mechanism:

  • Succinylcholine causes unsynchronised contractions of adjacent muscle fibres (fasciculations) before paralysis.
  • This leads to muscle damage, myoglobinemia, and elevated serum creatine kinase.
  • These findings correlate with the experience of postoperative myalgia, particularly in young, healthy adults.

Preventive Measures (with limited efficacy):

  • Pre-treatment with a defasciculating dose of nondepolarizing NMBD may prevent fasciculations, but evidence on reducing myalgia is inconclusive.
  • NSAIDs, such as lysine acetylsalicylate, show some effectiveness, suggesting a role for prostaglandins.
  • Rocuronium pre-treatment has been shown to reduce myalgia better than vecuronium or placebo.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Infants (Option A): Lower incidence due to less muscle mass and an immature neuromuscular system.

Burns patient (Option B): At risk for life-threatening hyperkalemia, not myalgia.

Elderly (Option C): Less prone to muscle pain due to decreased muscle mass and reduced postoperative mobility.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles is most resistant to non-depolarising neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diaphragm is significantly more resistant to non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agents (NDMRs) compared to peripheral muscles like the adductor pollicis. It requires 1.5 to 2 times the dose to achieve equivalent blockade.

This resistance is due to several factors:

  • Higher receptor density
  • Greater acetylcholine release
  • Possibly less acetylcholinesterase activity
  • Higher blood flow, which speeds up the onset and recovery

Despite its resistance, the diaphragm paradoxically shows a faster onset of action due to its rich blood supply, allowing more rapid drug delivery and equilibration. However, it also recovers sooner than the adductor pollicis.

Explanation of Other Options:

Rectus abdominis (Option A): This muscle is more sensitive to non-depolarising muscle relaxants than the diaphragm. It has slower onset and recovery due to relatively lower blood flow.

Adductor pollicis (Option B): One of the most sensitive muscles to NDMRs, often used in neuromuscular monitoring (e.g., TOF). It has slow onset and recovery, making it a late indicator of full muscle recovery.

Intercostal muscles (Option D): These are less resistant than the diaphragm but more resistant than the adductor pollicis. They play a role in respiration, and their blockade can contribute to respiratory compromise even when the diaphragm is still functioning.

questions.text: In obese patients, the dose of which muscle relaxant should be calculated based on total body weight rather than ideal body weight?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In obese patients, drug dosing depends on the pharmacokinetics of the medication, especially its volume of distribution and fat solubility.

  • Atracurium is dosed based on Total Body Weight (TBW) because its distribution is not significantly altered by body fat, and underdosing can lead to insufficient neuromuscular blockade.
  • It undergoes Hofmann elimination, which is organ-independent, so hepatic or renal clearance is not a limiting factor.

questions.text: Which of the following muscle relaxants can cause pain at the IV injection site?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rocuronium, a non-depolarising muscle relaxant, is known to cause pain at the injection site.
  • This pain is likely due to its acidic pH and osmolality.
  • The pain can be minimised by:
    • Diluting or alkalinising the solution, or
    • Pre-administration of lidocaine.
  • Rocuronium is the fastest-acting depolarising muscle relaxant (onset ~75 seconds).
  • It is a desacetoxy analogue of vecuronium with lower potency but faster onset (inverse relation between potency and onset).
  • Preferred for rapid sequence intubation in cases where succinylcholine is contraindicated.
  • Other drugs that can cause injection site pain:
    • Etomidate
    • Propofol
    • Methohexital
    • Thiopental

Explanation of other options:

Succinyl choline (Option A): Usually does not cause pain at the injection site. Its main side effects include fasciculations, postoperative myalgia, hyperkalemia, bradycardia or tachycardia and malignant hyperthermia (in susceptible individuals)

Vecuronium (Option B): It is painless on IV injection. It is hemodynamically stable, with minimal cardiovascular effects and does not release histamine.

Pancuronium (Option D): Also does not cause pain on injection. It is a long-acting, non-depolarising muscle relaxant. It is known for causing tachycardia (due to vagolytic effects) and hypertension

Reference: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9389860/

questions.text: A 25-year-old overweight female was given Fentanyl-Pancuronium anaesthesia for surgery. After surgery and extubation, she was observed to have limited movement of the upper body and chest wall in the recovery room. She was conscious and alert, but voluntary respiratory effort was limited. Her blood pressure and heart rate were normal. The likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pancuronium is a long-acting, non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker.
  • Residual paralysis (incomplete reversal) is a well-known issue, particularly with long-acting agents like pancuronium.
  • Limited voluntary respiratory effort with normal mental status and vitals strongly suggests muscle weakness due to residual NMBD effect, not sedation or opioid toxicity.
  • This is further supported by the lack of chest wall rigidity, hypoxia, or altered consciousness.
  • It is therefore imperative that all patients satisfy extubation criteria (Sustained head lift of more than 5 seconds or a strong hand grip) before removal of the tracheal tube.
  • The patient in question has limited movements of the upper body and hence is not satisfying the extubation criteria due to incomplete reversal /residual paralysis.

Explanation of other options:

Pulmonary embolism (Option A): Usually presents with sudden dyspnea, tachypnea, tachycardia possible chest pain and hypoxia. This patient has normal HR, BP, and is alert, which makes PE unlikely.

Respiratory depression (Option B): Seen with opioid overdose, sedatives, etc. Characterised by decreased respiratory rate, hypoventilation, and depressed mental status. Here, the patient is alert, which goes against opioid-induced respiratory depression.

Fentanyl-induced chest wall rigidity (Option C): Usually occurs with high-dose fentanyl during induction, in the initial phase of anaesthesia and presents as rigidity, not weakness, It also makes ventilation difficult, not typical after extubation.

choices.text: Causes hypotension & is reversed by neostigmine

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about d-Tubocurarine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

D-Tubocurarine (d-TC) is a long-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker, but:

  • Its duration of action is around 30-60 minutes, not 2–3 hours.
  • It acts as a competitive antagonist at nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction, preventing depolarisation and muscle contraction.

Explanation of other options:

Excreted unchanged by the kidney & bile (Option B): True. d-TC is excreted largely unchanged by the kidneys, with some biliary excretion. In renal impairment, its action may be prolonged.

Vagolytic & anaphylactic (Option C): True. It can block vagal tone, leading to tachycardia. It causes significant histamine release, increasing the risk of bronchospasm, hypotension, and anaphylaxis. It should be avoided in asthmatics and patients with reactive airway disease.

Causes hypotension & is reversed by neostigmine (Option D): True. It causes hypotension via autonomic ganglion blockade. Like all non-depolarising neuromuscular blockers, it is reversed by acetylcholinesterase inhibitors such as neostigmine.

questions.text: Which muscle relaxant is excreted exclusively by the kidney and is most sensitive in patients with myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Gallamine is a non-depolarizing muscle relaxant that is excreted almost entirely via the kidneys, making it unsuitable for patients with renal impairment.
  • It is also highly potent in individuals with myasthenia gravis, who are extremely sensitive to non-depolarizing muscle relaxants.
  • This increased sensitivity is due to the reduction in functional acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction in myasthenia gravis, making even small doses of these agents potent.

Anesthesia in Myasthenia Gravis:

  • Propofol and fentanyl are preferred induction agents in patients with myasthenia gravis.
  • They are short-acting, have minimal neuromuscular effects, and are safe alternatives to agents like thiopentone which may exacerbate weakness.

Reference:

https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6405345/#:

questions.text: A 40-year-old male has presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He has sustained major injuries and requires the airway to be relatively secured and protected. Any of the given muscle relaxants can be used in rapid sequence induction and intubation, except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Rapid Sequence Induction (RSI) requires:

  • A muscle relaxant with rapid onset (ideally ≤60-90 seconds)
  • Reliable intubating conditions
  • Short-to-intermediate duration of action

Atracurium:

  • Onset: ~2-3 minutes
  • Not suitable for rapid intubation
  • Histamine release can cause hypotension or bronchospasm
  • Ideal in renal/liver failure, but not for RSI
    → Too slow for RSI, hence not preferred

Explanation of other options:

Succinylcholine (Option A): Extremely rapid onset (30-60 sec) and short duration. It is the gold standard for RSI.

Rocuronium (Option C): Fast onset (60-90 sec) at higher doses; safe and reliable alternative to succinylcholine for RSI.

Vecuronium (Option B): Slower onset at usual doses, but higher doses (0.3 mg/kg) can achieve RSI conditions.

questions.text: In a patient with myasthenia gravis, which of the following is true in regards to muscle relaxants?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disease characterised by autoantibodies against the nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) on the postsynaptic membrane of the neuromuscular junction.
  • This leads to a reduced number of functional AChRs, resulting in skeletal muscle weakness and fatigability.

Reversal:

  • Traditional anticholinesterase (e.g., neostigmine) reversal is less predictable in MG due to baseline cholinesterase inhibition.
  • Sugammadex (for rocuronium/vecuronium) is preferred due to rapid, reliable reversal, though FDA approval for pediatric use is pending.

Volatile agents:

  • Volatile anaesthetics (like sevoflurane, isoflurane) can provide sufficient muscle relaxation alone in many cases, often eliminating the need for additional NMBDs.

Explanation of other options:

Resistant non-depolarising muscle relaxant (Option A): False - Increased sensitivity seen.

Sensitivity depolarising muscle relaxant (Option C): False - Relative resistance is common.

Increased acetylcholine receptors (Option D): False - The hallmark of MG is reduced functional AChRs.

questions.text: In a patient who has a neuromuscular condition, chronic denervation injury, what is true in regards to muscle relaxants?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chronic denervation injuries (e.g., spinal cord injury, motor neuron disease, long-standing paralysis) result in significant changes at the neuromuscular junction that impact how patients respond to neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs).

  • Upregulation of ACh Receptors:
    • Within 4-5 days of denervation, acetylcholine (ACh) receptors are no longer restricted to the motor endplate, but instead spread across the entire muscle membrane (extra-junctional receptors proliferate).
  • Consequences:
    • Depolarising NMBDs (e.g., succinylcholine):
      • Dangerously increased potassium release from the widespread ACh receptor activation.
      • Risk of life-threatening hyperkalemia.
      • Hence, contraindicated in chronic denervation conditions.
    • Non-depolarising NMBDs:
      • There may be resistance to non-depolarising agents due to increased receptor numbers, requiring larger doses for effect.
      • However, the response is unpredictable, and individual titration is necessary.

Explanation of other options:

Resistant non-depolarising muscle relaxants (Option A): True, but not the only effect.

Increased acetylcholine receptors (Option B): True, due to denervation.

Sensitivity-depolarising muscle relaxants (Option C): True, dangerously exaggerated K+ response.

questions.text: Identify the complementary pair of antagonists
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Warfarin: Its anticoagulant effect can be reversed by administering vitamin K, which promotes the synthesis of clotting factors II, VII, IX, and X. In cases of severe bleeding, prothrombin complex concentrate (PCC) or fresh frozen plasma (FFP) may also be used.
  • Heparin: A highly negatively charged molecule; its effects neutralised by protamine sulphate, a positively charged compound that forms a stable complex with heparin, thus inhibiting its anticoagulant activity.
  • Morphine: An opioid analgesic. Its effects are competitively reversed by naloxone, a high-affinity opioid receptor antagonist, especially at the μ (MOP) receptor
  • Vecuronium is a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker. Its action is reversed by neostigmine, an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor, which increases acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, overcoming the blockade.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presented to the emergency department following a road traffic accident. He had sustained major injuries and required his airway to be secured and protected. He was managed primarily. He returns 2 months later for contracture release. Which of the following drugs is to be avoided?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In patients with burn injuries, there is a rapid and sustained upregulation of both fetal and mature nicotinic acetylcholine receptors (nAChRs) on the muscle membrane. This change begins within 24-72 hours after the injury and can persist for months to years, depending on the extent of injury and healing.
  • When succinylcholine, a depolarising neuromuscular blocker, is administered after this period, it binds to the upregulated receptors and causes massive potassium efflux, leading to life-threatening hyperkalemia.
  • Serum potassium levels as high as 13 mEq/L have been reported, causing ventricular arrhythmias, cardiac arrest, and death. This risk is not proportional to the burn size; even minor burns (~8% TBSA) have resulted in fatal outcomes.
  • Thus, succinylcholine is contraindicated after 24 hours of a burn injury and should be avoided for at least years post-injury, or until complete healing and reperfusion.

Explanation of other options:

Vecuronium (Option B): A non-depolarising NMBD. Although some resistance may develop due to receptor upregulation, it does not cause hyperkalemia and is therefore safe. Dosage may need adjustment.

Rocuronium (Option C): A non-depolarising NMBD. Safe in burn patients. It is often used as an alternative to succinylcholine for rapid sequence intubation, especially when hyperkalemia is a concern.

Atracurium (Option D): A non-depolarising NMBD that undergoes Hofmann elimination, making it independent of renal or hepatic clearance. It is safe and predictable in burn patients.

choices.text: Dysrhythmias frequently occur following intramuscular injections

questions.text: Which of the following statements concerning the side effects of succinylcholine when used to paralyse neonates is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In neonates, intramuscular (IM) administration of succinylcholine is associated with a lower incidence of bradyarrhythmias compared to IV dosing.
  • Dysrhythmias are less frequent when the drug is given IM, making this statement false, as required by the question.

Explanation of other options:

It seldom causes muscle fasciculations (Option A): True. Neonates and infants have immature neuromuscular junctions and lower muscle tone, which results in minimal or absent fasciculations when succinylcholine is administered. This is a known difference from older children and adults.

It can cause bradycardia (Option B): True. Bradycardia is a common side effect, particularly in neonates and infants, and is more likely when succinylcholine is given intravenously. This is due to parasympathetic stimulation via muscarinic receptors, especially with repeated dosing.

It can cause myoglobinuria (Option D): True. Succinylcholine can cause rhabdomyolysis, particularly in children with undiagnosed muscular dystrophy, leading to myoglobinuria. This is a serious adverse effect and contributes to the risk of renal damage and hyperkalemia.

questions.text: Administration of vecuronium during spinal surgery may interfere with the monitoring of:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Vecuronium interferes with EPs and thus impairs monitoring of the corticospinal tract, which is the motor pathway.

During spinal surgery, especially procedures like scoliosis correction, intraoperative neurophysiological monitoring (IONM) is used to detect early signs of spinal cord injury and guide the surgical team.

Two major types of spinal cord pathways are monitored:

1. Dorsal Columns (Sensory Pathways)

  • Monitored using Somatosensory Evoked Potentials (SSEPs).
  • SSEPs involve stimulating peripheral nerves and recording responses over the scalp.
  • Neuromuscular blockers like vecuronium do not interfere with SSEPs, as these reflect sensory conduction, not motor output.

2. Corticospinal Tract (Motor Pathways)

  • Monitored using Motor Evoked Potentials (MEPs).
  • MEPs require the transmission of electrical signals through the motor system and muscle response.
  • Neuromuscular blockers (e.g., vecuronium) block neuromuscular transmission and therefore suppress MEP responses, making them unreliable.

Explanation of other options:

Dorsal columns (Option A): Monitored by SSEPs; not affected by vecuronium.

ECoG (Electrocorticography) (Option C): Measures cortical electrical activity; influenced by antiepileptics or anaesthetics, not muscle relaxants.

Bispectral index (Option D): Reflects depth of anaesthesia via EEG processing; unaffected by neuromuscular blockers.

questions.text: Neuromuscular blocking agents can cause dyselectrolytemia. This includes depolarising agents like succinylcholine. Succinylcholine, when administered to patients, can increase serum potassium by approximately:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Succinylcholine is a depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent that mimics acetylcholine and binds to nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Upon binding, it causes a sustained polarisation by keeping the ion channels open longer than acetylcholine. This results in the efflux of intracellular potassium into the bloodstream.
  • In normal individuals, this potassium shift typically raises serum potassium by approximately5 mEq/L, which is clinically insignificant in most cases.
  • Even in patients with stable renal failure, this mild rise is usually tolerated, provided there is no existing hyperkalemia or receptor upregulation (e.g., burns, neuromuscular disease, prolonged immobilisation).
  • In patients with denervation injuries, burns, or muscular dystrophies, the potassium increase can be much higher and potentially life-threatening due to upregulation of extrajunctional receptors.

questions.text: Among the non-depolarising muscle relaxants, a few exhibit vagolytic properties. They are:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agents (ND-NMBAs) can exhibit vagolytic (antimuscarinic) properties, leading to tachycardia and increased cardiac output by inhibiting vagal tone at the sinoatrial (SA) node.

Pancuronium:

  • Pancuronium is well-known for its significant vagolytic effect.
  • It inhibits cardiac muscarinic receptors, especially at the SA node.
  • This results in tachycardia and mild hypertension.
  • It may also cause increased catecholamine release.

Rocuronium:

  • Rocuronium has a milder vagolytic effect compared to pancuronium.
  • It can still cause slight increases in heart rate, especially at higher doses or in combination with other agents affecting autonomic tone.

Atracurium:

  • Atracurium does not have vagolytic activity. (Option C ruled out)
  • It may cause hypotension and flushing, but this is due to histamine release, not vagolysis.

questions.text: The non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent (ND-NMBA) with the shortest duration of action is:
questions.solution:
Explanation for the answer:

Mivacurium is a short-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocking agent that belongs to the benzylisoquinolinium group.

  • It is hydrolysed rapidly by plasma pseudocholinesterase, similar to succinylcholine.
  • Its onset is about 2-3 minutes, and its duration of action is approximately 15-20 minutes, making it the shortest-acting non-depolarising muscle relaxant in clinical use.

This makes Mivacurium particularly useful for short procedures or in cases where rapid recovery of neuromuscular function is desirable.

Explanation of other options:

Pipecuronium (Option B): It is a long-acting aminosteroid NMBA with a duration of action of 60-90 minutes. It is mainly eliminated by the kidneys.

Pancuronium (Option C): It is a long-acting aminosteroid NMBA with a duration of action of  60-90 minutes. It has vagolytic effects and is dependent on renal clearance.

Vecuronium (Option D): It is an intermediate-acting aminosteroid NMBA with a duration of action of 30-45 minutes. It is eliminated via hepatic and renal routes.

Key takeaway:

Reference:

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537168/

choices.text: General anesthesia with non-depolarization muscle relaxant

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents with a penetrating injury to the eye. He needs a globe repair. His anaesthesia management will be:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In penetrating eye injuries like a ruptured globe, anaesthetic management aims to:

  • Prevent rises in intraocular pressure (IOP)
  • Ensure smooth induction and immobility
  • Secure the airway safely under general anaesthesia

Non-depolarising neuromuscular blockers like rocuronium are preferred in open-globe injuries because:

  • They do not significantly increase IOP
  • Rocuronium at high doses (1.0-1.2 mg/kg) provides rapid onset comparable to succinylcholine
  • It has a predictable duration and is reversible with sugammadex if needed

This makes it ideal for rapid sequence induction when succinylcholine is not preferred due to the risk of increasing IOP.

Explanation of other options:

Lignocaine infiltration (Option A): It is inadequate for deep ocular surgery and doesn’t offer airway protection or control over IOP.

Topical propacaine (Option B): Only used for minor surface procedures (like corneal abrasion checks); it cannot provide anaesthesia or immobility for globe repair.

General anaesthesia with succinylcholine (Option C): Succinylcholine is known to increase IOP for a few minutes after administration (as much as 8–10 mm Hg). While this rise is transient and clinically insignificant in most eye surgeries, it is still avoided in open-globe injuries due to the theoretical risk of vitreous extrusion.

choices.text: A I, B III, C II
A IV, B II, C III
A I, B III, C IV
A I, B II, C III

questions.text: Regarding the following image, match the following.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Reference: https://intraoperativeneuromonitoring.com/train-of-four/

choices.text: The induction dose of propofol should be calculated using total body weight
The initial dose of midazolam should be calculated using total body weight
Remifentanil dose should be calculated using lean body weight
Suxamethonium dose should be calculated using lean body weight

questions.text: Which of the given statements is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Succinylcholine (suxamethonium) is a depolarising neuromuscular blocker used for rapid sequence induction. Its dose should be calculated based on total body weight (TBW), not lean body weight (LBW), even in obese patients.

  • Succinylcholine has a high volume of distribution.
  • It is rapidly hydrolysed by plasma pseudocholinesterase, so more drug is needed in larger patients (who have higher enzyme levels).
  • Underdosing (if based on lean body weight) can lead to inadequate paralysis, making intubation difficult or dangerous.
  • Therefore, dosing based on total body weight ensures effective neuromuscular blockade.

Explanation of the Other Options:

Induction dose of propofol should be calculated using total body weight (Option A): Propofol distributes into fat and lean tissue. For induction, dosing based on TBW provides appropriate depth of anaesthesia. However, for maintenance in obese patients, LBW may be preferred to avoid overdose.

The initial dose of midazolam should be calculated using total body weight (Option B): For bolus (initial) sedation, TBW is used. Caution is required in obese or elderly patients, but technically, this statement is correct.

Remifentanil dose should be calculated using lean body weight (Option C): Remifentanil is rapidly metabolised by plasma esterases and is not stored in fat. Hence, it is dosed based on lean body weight to avoid overdose.

questions.text: Which of the following doses of Sugammadex should be used to reverse neuromuscular blockade in an 85 kg man who received 100mg of rocuronium bromide 3 minutes ago?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The patient received 100 mg of rocuronium 3 minutes ago, which indicates deep neuromuscular blockade (i.e., no or only 1 twitch on TOF). This requires a high-dose reversal using Sugammadex.

Since only 3 minutes have passed since rocuronium administration, the block is likely deep.

However, in this question, the patient received 100 mg rocuronium, which is ~1.17 mg/kg — near rapid sequence intubation dose (1.2 mg/kg).

Because Sugammadex is being given only 3 minutes after rocuronium, it falls under "immediate reversal", which requires: 16 mg/kg of Sugammadex

So: 16 mg/kg × 85 kg = 1360 mg

Reference:

https://anaesthesiology.gr/media/File/pdf/WFSA%20tutorial%20332%20An%20Overview%20of%20Sugammadex.pdf

choices.text: Neostigmine is its only reversal agent.
Does not exhibit fade and post-tetanic potentiation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man has presented for emergency repair of torsion of the testis. He is fit and well but has a known allergy to suxamethonium. He had lunch 4 hours ago. A modified rapid sequence induction with rocuronium is planned. Which of the following best describes rocuronium?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rocuronium is a non-depolarising muscle relaxant belonging to the aminosteroid group, just like vecuronium and pancuronium.
  • It is chemically and pharmacologically related to vecuronium but has a faster onset, making it suitable for rapid sequence induction (RSI) when suxamethonium is contraindicated.

Explanation of other options:

Neostigmine is its only reversal agent (Option B): False. While neostigmine can reverse rocuronium-induced blockade, sugammadex is a specific binding agent that reverses rocuronium more rapidly and reliably. So, neostigmine is not the only reversal agent.

Does not exhibit fade and post-tetanic potentiation (Option C): False. Rocuronium, being a non-depolarising agent, does exhibit Fade on Train-of-Four (TOF) stimulation and Post-tetanic potentiation These features help differentiate it from depolarising blockers like suxamethonium.

Causes hyperkalemia (Option D): False. Rocuronium does not cause hyperkalemia. Succinylcholine is the agent known to increase serum potassium, especially in patients with burns, trauma, neuromuscular disease, or prolonged immobility.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man has a rapid sequence induction for a perforated duodenal ulcer. Twenty minutes later, his heart rate rises to 125 beats per minute, blood pressure decreases to 75/40 mmHg, airway pressures increase to 36 cmH2O, and cutaneous urticaria is rapidly spreading. What is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) are the most common cause of perioperative anaphylaxis, responsible for up to 60% of cases.
  • Among NMBAs, succinylcholine is a frequent trigger, particularly because it can directly activate mast cells, leading to:
    • Hypotension
    • Bronchospasm
    • Urticaria
    • Tachycardia
  • Other NMBAs commonly associated with the development of anaphylaxis:
    • Rocuronium (high risk)
    • Atracurium (moderate risk)
    • Vecuronium (moderate risk)
    • Mivacurium (moderate risk)
    • Cisatracurium (low risk)
    • Pancuronium (rare)

This patient's presentation within 20 minutes of induction supports NMBA-induced IgE-mediated hypersensitivity.

Explanation of other options:

Atracurium (Option B): Can cause histamine release, but true anaphylaxis is less frequent compared to succinylcholine. It is more associated with gradual hypotension and flushing, not full-blown anaphylaxis.

Latex (Option C): Latex allergy is a known cause of anaphylaxis, but reactions are usually delayed and occur after surgical exposure, not so early after induction.

Fentanyl (Option D): Fentanyl can rarely cause mild histamine release, but it very rarely causes true anaphylaxis. Tachycardia and bronchospasm are not commonly associated with fentanyl reactions.

Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4173455/

questions.text: A 75-year-old woman undergoing mitral valve repair is induced with high-dose fentanyl, which causes bradycardia. To counteract this, pancuronium is administered. Which site does pancuronium act upon to block fentanyl-induced bradycardia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pancuronium is a non-depolarising aminosteroid neuromuscular blocker that also possesses vagolytic properties. It increases heart rate by blocking muscarinic M2 receptors at the sinoatrial (SA) node in the heart. These receptors are part of the parasympathetic system (vagal tone).
  • When fentanyl causes bradycardia, pancuronium antagonizes this effect by peripherally inhibiting cardiac muscarinic receptors, thus reducing vagal input and increasing heart rate.

Explanation of other options:

β-Adrenergic receptors (Option A): Incorrect because pancuronium is not a β-agonist and does not act through β-adrenergic receptor stimulation. Its effect on heart rate is vagolytic, not sympathetic in origin.

Carotid baroreceptors (Option C): These are pressure sensors in the carotid sinus that detect changes in blood pressure and adjust heart rate via autonomic feedback loops. Pancuronium does not directly affect baroreceptors, nor is fentanyl-induced bradycardia mediated through them.

Central vagal nuclei (Option D): Fentanyl acts here to increase parasympathetic output, causing bradycardia. However, pancuronium does not cross the blood-brain barrier and therefore does not act centrally at the vagal nuclei. It exerts its effects peripherally, making this option incorrect.

Reference:

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/4249029/

questions.text: A woman with impending eclampsia is taken for emergency lower-segment cesarean section (LSCS). After induction with succinylcholine, a decrease in fasciculations is observed. Which factor is most likely responsible for this blunted fasciculatory response?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Succinylcholine, a depolarising muscle relaxant, normally causes fasciculations as it depolarises nicotinic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.
  • Magnesium sulfate, which is often administered for eclampsia prophylaxis or treatment, acts as a physiologic calcium antagonist.
  • Magnesium:
    • Reduces acetylcholine release from presynaptic neurons
    • Inhibits calcium entry required for synaptic vesicle fusion
    • Stabilises postsynaptic membranes
  • As a result, magnesium blunts neuromuscular transmission, leading to less intense or absent fasciculations after succinylcholine.

Explanation of other options:

Increased cardiac output (Option A): May alter drug distribution slightly, but does not directly blunt fasciculations.

Prior nitrous oxide inhalation (Option C): Nitrous oxide is not known to reduce fasciculations and has no effect on neuromuscular transmission at this level.

Metabolic alkalosis (Option D): Alkalosis can increase neuromuscular excitability, potentially enhancing fasciculations rather than reducing them

questions.text: A 50-year-old male who has a case of pleomorphic adenoma is posted for superficial parotidectomy. The muscle relaxant of choice is?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Superficial parotidectomy involves facial nerve dissection, and preservation of the facial nerve is a key surgical objective.
  • To identify and preserve the facial nerve, surgeons often use intraoperative nerve monitoring or stimulation.
  • Neuromuscular blocking agents (NMBAs) interfere with this process because they:
    • Block transmission at the neuromuscular junction
    • Prevent motor responses during facial nerve stimulation
  • Therefore, muscle relaxants are typically avoided during such surgeries to allow functional nerve identification.

Explanation of other options:

Vecuronium (Option A): Non-depolarising relaxant; would prevent nerve monitoring.

Succinylcholine (Option B): Depolarising; though short-acting, it would still interfere with nerve response if present.

Rocuronium (Option C): Non-depolarising; similar disadvantages as vecuronium.
